title: BAE Systems wins $450 million contract to build weather satellite instrument
summary: BAE Systems won a $450 contract to develop an ocean-color instrument for the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration’s next geostationary weather constellation.

title: Viasat taps OneWeb to provide multi-orbit maritime broadband
summary: Geostationary fleet operator Viasat is buying capacity from OneWeb’s low Earth orbit satellites for maritime customers in the latest multi-orbit challenge to Starlink’s growing dominance.

title: How Privateer aims to slash Earth imagery costs
summary: Privateer’s recent acquisition of Orbital Insight sheds new light on the Hawaiian startup’s ambitious plans, which are likely to include future acquisitions.

title: Starfish Space lands $37.5 million Space Force contract for on-orbit servicing vehicle
summary: Starfish’s Otter space tug would provide “augmented maneuvering” capabilities to military satellites

title: The Atlantic hurricane season begins soon—hold on to your butts
summary: One reputable forecast team predicts 33 named storms.

title: Space Force plans deep-dive study on pros and cons of orbital refueling
summary: Col. Rich Kniseley: ‘We need to make sure there is a business case for commercial companies to survive if the government is not there’

title: National Security Memorandum-22 omitted space entirely. Here’s a path forward.
summary: As the stardust settles after the release of NSM-22, the space community should take a moment to see the opportunity it has been presented.

title: China launches four high-resolution remote sensing satellites
summary: China sent a new set of four Beijing-3 optical remote sensing satellites into orbit late Sunday.

title: Ed Dwight “Ecstatic” At Finally Reaching Space
summary: Ed Dwight, who went through training in the early days of the space program that he thought would make him NASA’s first black astronaut, fulfilled his dream of seeing Earth […]

title: Blue Origin resumes crewed New Shepard suborbital flights
summary: Blue Origin conducted its first crewed New Shepard mission in nearly two years May 19, carrying six people, including the first American Black astronaut candidate, on a suborbital spaceflight the company called a success despite a parachute issue.
